Les principaux constats montrent que 45% des enfants abandonnent l'√©cole avant la fin du primaire, tandis que 24% n'ont pas d'acte de naissance, ce qui bloque leur parcours scolaire au CM2. Les mines artisanales capturent une main-d'≈ìuvre juv√©nile significative, avec 45% des travailleurs √¢g√©s de moins de 18 ans, attir√©s par des revenus imm√©diats comme 3 000 FCFA par jour. Les conditions de vie extr√™mes aggravent la situation : 95% des familles sans √©lectricit√©, 92% sans acc√®s √† l'eau potable et 78% vivant √† plus de 10 km d'un centre de sant√©. Malgr√© ce tableau sombre, l'enqu√™te a identifi√© des √Ælots d'espoir, comme le taux de scolarisation de 95% chez les enfants Baka de 6 √† 12 ans, et des cas exemplaires comme celui de Sakinatou, jeune polyglotte de Bindia.
executive_summary.en: The survey conducted by Raise-Up Cameroon (RUC) in the East Region reveals an alarming educational situation where 85% of registered families are forced to sacrifice the schooling of at least one child. Key findings show that 45% of children drop out of school before completing primary education, while 24% lack birth certificates, blocking their educational progression at the CM2 level. Artisanal mines capture significant juvenile labor, with 45% of workers aged under 18, attracted by immediate daily earnings of 3,000 FCFA. Extreme living conditions exacerbate the situation: 95% of families without electricity, 92% without access to drinking water, and 78% living more than 10 km from a health center. Despite this bleak picture, the survey identified beacons of hope, such as the 95% enrollment rate among Baka children aged 6-12, and exemplary cases like that of Sakinatou, a young polyglot from Bindia.
